results:
Based on the search results, I've found comprehensive information about Pan Tadeusz by Adam Mickiewicz and its 1834 first edition. Here's what the search revealed:

## Pan Tadeusz - 1834 First Edition and Original Manuscript

### Publication Details
The book, written in Polish alexandrines, was first published by Aleksander Jełowicki on 28 June 1834 in Paris.(no content)Originally published: First published in Paris in 1834 (in two volumes)

### Original Manuscript Information
The original manuscript has a fascinating history:

The manuscript of "Pan Tadeusz" does not include the whole work, but it contains excerpts from all twelve books of the poem, both from the draft and final copies.(no content)The manuscript consists of two parts bound together: a notebook in a soft cardboard cover of 48 pages and an album of 91 pages. The whole book is bound in red kid leather cover.

### Recently Discovered Manuscript Fragment
This piece of paper was found in 2015 in Lviv in the collection of the Central State Historical Archive of Ukraine. Written on it are the first forty verses of "Pan Tadeusz czyli ostatni zajazd na Litwie.(no content)an epic poem that the Polish Romantic poet Adam Mickiewicz (1798-1855), inspired by love and longing for his homeland, created while in Paris (1832-1834).

### Current Location and Preservation
Pan Tadeusz is required reading in Polish schools, and its original manuscript is considered to be the most important holding of the Ossolineum. The original manuscript is on display in the Pan Tadeusz Museum in Wrocław, which opened in 2016.(no content)The manuscript is kept in an elegant ebony box, produced in 1873 to a design by the Cracow sculptor Józef Brzostowski. The chest is additionally decorated with bas-reliefs engraved in ivory, on the side walls there are reliefs made to drawings by Juliusz Kossak, depicting scenes from the poem.

### UNESCO Recognition
In 2014 Pan Tadeusz was incorporated into Poland's list in the UNESCO Memory of the World Programme.(no content)The manuscript of "Pan Tadeusz" was incorporated into Poland's List in the UNESCO Memory of the World Programme in 2014 as a valuable monument of Polish culture, a historical memento and a carrier of national values.

The search revealed extensive information about both the 1834 first edition published in Paris and the original manuscript materials, including recently discovered fragments and their current preservation status.
